Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Try using gRPC with mac hosts again
Description: A few months ago, I tested communicating with the Mac hosts using gRPC instead of SSH because SSH is fragile and highly dependent on the SSH command producing well-formed output. I'm pretty sure I also filed a ticket to allow the app servers to reach out to Jasper on the Mac hosts over gRPC, but it didn't work even after the ticket was closed. Since the annoyance around relying on SSH output has arisen again recently, it's worth trying again and diagnosing why exactly gRPC isn't working.

Title: Make temporary distro setting for requesting user data script from the app server
Description: The goal is to eventually migrate all user data-provisioned distros to just request the script from the app server within user data rather than pass the entire script in the initial AWS instance request. Assuming the transition won't go smoothly for every single distro, make a flag that will turn it on selectively for distros until we have some confidence that it works.    We can remove the setting once all user data distros have been migrated.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Request the full host provisioning script from the app server in user data
Description: The user data script only needs to contain the bare minimum information necessary (e.g. host ID, host secret, the REST endpoint to curl) to ask the app server for the full user data script text, which it can then execute.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Create CLI command to execute user data script
Description: Make a CLI command that executes the user data script once it's been fetched from the application server.         This might just be a small modification of {{evergreen host setup}}, especially given that the command can handle both bash and powershell scripts.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Request host provisioning script from the app server
Description: The script to provision the host is currently one long shell script that gets sent as the user data payload with the request to launch the instance. This can fail if the script is bigger than 16kB. One way to resolve this is to reduce the user data script sent to the instance so that all it does is fetch the actual provisioning script from the app server and execute it. This effectively removes the 16kB limit.

(Do this only if one doesn’t exist, since this may be toggled on and off.)For existing projects, this should also set Shortname to Identifier.After this flag is turned on, any new projects that are created should be given a unique identifier.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Codegen is flaky when run locally
Description: Not sure if this is an issue affecting just me or not. When I run the codegen tests (i.e. {{make test-rest-model RUN_TEST=TestCodegen}}), it will fail maybe 30-50% of the time, and each time will be a different failing test. It may be goimports-related because when the tests fail, it'll be because the import statement is missing. I ran this on go1.14.5 (codegen has been tested on go1.15 before).    It also outputs this error:  {{gopathwalk: scanning directory ${GOPATH}/src: readdirent: permission denied}}  I'm not sure if it's related or not though, because it always prints that error and sometimes the codegen tests still succeed.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Handle custom builds when downloading binaries on hosts from S3
Description: Staging will not download binaries from S3, but production will (to reduce load on the server during deploys). In order for production to download from S3, the binaries must have been uploaded to the desired location in S3 or else binary downloads will fail. Because custom builds may or may not have uploaded the binaries to the S3 location, we have to come up with a way to do one of the following:   # Disable downloading binaries from S3 (so that it downloads from the app server). I'm assuming that people will _not_ remember  (or know) to disable the admin setting flag for downloading from S3 (EVG-13258) when deploying a custom build to production.   # Guarantee that the binaries are uploaded in the correct location in S3.    There's several options to deal with this, with some options such as:   * Add a large warning text when someone deploys a custom build to production (easy, but you still have to see the text in the output).   * As a pre-deploy step, require that the binaries in dist.tar.gz be uploaded to S3 before deploying the custom build. This would slow down custom build deploys, but would allow the binaries to be downloaded from S3 and would not require any database changes (slowest option, but would require no code changes to deal with it in the application code).   * When deploying a custom build, disable the database feature flag for using S3 URLs vs. app server URLs to download binaries.   * Modify host provisioning to try downloading the binary from S3 first, and download from the app server as a fallback. If it fails to download from S3 (due to 403/404), fall back to downloading it from the app server. This could be a bit wasteful in provisioning time, but assuming custom build deploys are uncommon, it might not be that bad in terms of performance.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Improve gRPC protobuf sharing story
Description: We should improve how clients import the gRPC protobufs from cedar, or any of our services that use gRPC servers. I already created a [repo|https://github.com/evergreen-ci/juniper] to store the protobuf files for more consistent updating and importing and to avoid collisions. We can do more interesting things, especially for c++ and python clients, such as making use of our CI system and package repos (for example, each time juniper gets updates, evergreen is triggered to re-generate the pb files calling `make proto <langauge_name>` for supported langauges and push the generated files to a package repos.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Create admin flag to enable/disable download agent from S3
Description: There are some cases where we don't want to download the agent from S3:   * Uploading custom builds in staging will not be able to get them from S3 unless the developer also uploads them to S3 (which can be time-consuming).   * During outages, it may not be possible to run the task that puts the agent in S3, which would prevent agents from being downloaded.    In these cases, we should have an admin setting that toggles whether to download the host's binary from the app server or from S3.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: How does mistuning cause 9-hour waits?
Description: This distro has an unusual task pattern. A large number of tasks are created around midnight UCT. It takes about 9 hours to work through the backlog. I can almost guarantee that some tasks waited the entire 9 hours before they started. However, operational parameters are normal. No hosts were terminated externally, global total dynamic hosts limit was not reached, and distro max hosts limit was not reached. Clearly, some parameter or other is mistuned. What parameters, and how can we fix this?

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Do not create tickets for setup-failed tasks
Description: *Request*    Setup-failed tasks do not warrant investigation, so we should not create tickets for them.     *Context*    No one has been triaging BFGs that fail as setup-failed. I reached out to [~<USER> to ask if Build should be investigating these failures, but they are filtering out these BFGs on purpose. These BFGs are caused by intermittent issues like network, app deployments, server restarts. They normally recover when restarted so having someone looking at those is a waste of resources.         Only 0.5% of these BFGs were [resolved as Duplicate|https://jira.mongodb.org/issues/?jql=project%20%3D%20BFG%20and%20%22Failure%20Type%22%20%3D%20setup-failed%20and%20resolution%20%3D%20Duplicate] of an existing BF, and 98% of these BFGs are [resolved as Incomplete|https://jira.mongodb.org/issues/?jql=project%20%3D%20BFG%20and%20%22Failure%20Type%22%20%3D%20setup-failed%20and%20resolution%20%3D%20Incomplete] through the validator that closes BFGs that do not get investigated within 30 days.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Group tasks by status in grid sidebar on the patch details page, rather than loading individual task boxes
Description: h3. This new interface reduces information clutter and improves performance by reducing the number of individual task boxes shown on the patch details page. These are two key themes of the Mainline Commits UI project. Please note that this interface may be subject to change as more progress is made with the designs for Mainline Commits UI project.     This change addresses the most severe performance issues noted in EVG-12710. Additionally, it allows users to more clearly identify and keep track of their patch failures, particularly for patches with large numbers of tasks, since they no longer need to pick out individual red boxes. This patch also includes optimizations to more quickly filter by variant and by status within a variant.     Users can filter by variant by clicking on variant titles (EVG-13111). Users can filter to tasks within a variant by clicking on the individual boxes.     !Screen Shot 2020-10-13 at 3.29.07 PM.png|width=40%! Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: take generated tasks into account when generating slowdowns for post hoc task analysis
Description: display_version_slowdown currently does not correctly take into account the implicit dependency in task generation. It only looks at depends_on. display_only tasks are said to depend_on the tasks that the tasks they generate depend on, but can start well before these tasks. This leads to instances, such as mongodb_mongo_master_fbafa599da8f316e508d0a152586a77e85805c29 , where the slowdown is less than zero. Additionally, The topological ordering of the task DAG implicitly treats generated tasks as equivalent in start time to tasks scheduled at the very beginning. This could lead to an underestimate, rather than overestimate, of idealized runtime. I think the following approach will correct this:    Remove dependencies of display_only tasks.    Create a dummy generator node, whose end time is equivalent to the time of the generated task's creation, whose start time is equivalent to the generator task's start time, and which ¿depends on the same tasks as the generator task, if genuine dependencies can be found?  depends on. This embeds the dependency implied by ordering of task scheduling/creation time into the structure of the graph.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Include display task name in test results
Description: We need this for the historical stats, because in the case of test results within execution tasks within a display task, the test results are considered part of the single display task. Cedar doesn't currently deal with display tasks, so it'll have to know what each execution task's display task is.    The display task is optional because regular tasks will not have execution tasks within them. For this, we'll have to deal with it in the S3 bucket prefix by allowing an optional display task name in the prefix if it's set.

While doing so, I found that whether or not I pass Description request field, the description gets erased. Please see examples bellow.    It would be amazing if we could have it not modify the description, or populate it correctly. Additionally, it would be amazing if as part of this improvement we could somehow provide * for tasks or default to all tasks if only id is provided for the variant and not tasks.    Examples:    {code:python}  # Got patch id for pr = https://github.com/10gen/mms/pull/33557  update = {      description: My PR,      variants: [          {              id: package_rpm,              tasks: [                  PACKAGE_OPS_MANAGER              ]          }      ]  }  requests.post(https://evergreen.mongodb.com/api/rest/v2/patches/5f7239e5e3c3310fbefb9d43/configure, data=json.dumps(update), headers=auth_header)      result: https://spruce.mongodb.com/patch/5f7233b261837d5d228f31df (patch name is erased)

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Allow removing a buildvariant from a matrix
Description: It would be nice to allow removing a variant altogether from a matrix.    My use case is that I am generating a matrix where the axes are Swift language version and operating system.    For one particular combination of Swift version and OS, I do not want a corresponding variant because the language version is not supported on the OS version.    It would be nice to have a remove_variants rule similar to remove_tasks that allows you to specify variants to remove.    Currently, my workaround is to define a separate matrix for the Swift language version in question and list out all the OSes except the problematic one as values for the OS axis. This works, but the duplication is not ideal.    Note that adding a {{remove_tasks: *}} rule with the corresponding OS/language version criteria does not work, because it results in a variant with no tasks, and Evergreen enforces that each variant has at least one task.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Poplar / Cedar not handling events streamed out of order safely
Description: In [this|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/sys_perf_linux_standalone_large_scale_model_patch_46a7656f3c4805dc6ffff32573886b00a4e63888_5f690ab57742ae290c31fe8e_20_09_21_20_20_32##hidden=large_scale_model%252CLongLivedCreator.TotalBulkInsert%252CLongLivedCreator.IndividualBulkInsert%252CLongLivedCreator.IndexBuild%252CLongLivedIndexReader.Query%252CLongLivedReader.Query%252CLongLivedWriter.Update%252CRollingManage.CreateCollection.2.2%252CRollingManage.DeleteCollection.2.2%252CRollingWriter.Insert.2.2%252CRollingReader1.Find.2.2%252CRollingReader2.Find.2.2%252CHotDocumentLoader.TotalBulkInsert%252CHotDocumentLoader.IndividualBulkInsert%252CHotDocumentLoader.IndexBuild%252CHotDocumentUpdater.Crud%252CHotDocumentUpdater.bulkWrite%252CHotCollectionLoader.TotalBulkInsert%252CHotCollectionLoader.IndividualBulkInsert%252CHotCollectionLoader.IndexBuild%252CHotCollectionUpdater.Crud%252CHotCollectionUpdater.bulkWrite%252CHotCollectionDeleter.Delete.2.2%252CScannerLoader.TotalBulkInsert%252CScannerLoader.IndividualBulkInsert%252CScannerLoader.IndexBuild%252CSnapshotScanner1Gigabytes.Insert%252CSnapshotScanner1Gigabytes.Scan.2.2%252CSnapshotScanner1Gigabytes.ExceptionsCaught.2.2%252CSnapshotScanner5Gigabytes.Insert%252CSnapshotScanner5Gigabytes.Scan.2.2%252CSnapshotScanner5Gigabytes.ExceptionsCaught.2.2%252CSnapshotScannerAll.Insert%252CSnapshotScannerAll.Scan.2.2%252CSnapshotScannerAll.ExceptionsCaught.2.2%252COplogTailer.OplogLag.2.2%252CLargeScaleModel.Setup%252CLargeScaleModel.ActorStarted%252CLargeScaleModel.ActorFinished%252CLongLivedWriter.Update.2%252Ccanary_server-cpuloop-10x%252Ccanary_client-cpuloop-1x%252Ccanary_client-cpuloop-10x%252Ccanary_server-sleep-10ms%252Ccanary_ping%252Cfio_latency_test_write_clat_mean%252Cfio_latency_test_read_clat_mean%252Cfio_iops_test_write_iops%252Cfio_iops_test_read_iops%252Cfio_streaming_bandwidth_test_write_iops%252Cfio_streaming_bandwidth_test_read_iops%252CNetworkBandwidth&comparehashes=46a7656f3c4805dc6ffff32573886b00a4e63888&metric=OperationThroughput&threads=all&selected.large_scale_model=&selected.LongLivedCreator.TotalBulkInsert=&selected.LongLivedCreator.IndividualBulkInsert=&selected.LongLivedCreator.IndexBuild=&selected.LongLivedIndexReader.Query=10&selected.LongLivedReader.Query=&selected.LongLivedWriter.Update.2=&selected.RollingManage.CreateCollection.2.2=&selected.RollingManage.DeleteCollection.2.2=&selected.RollingWriter.Insert.2.2=40&selected.RollingReader1.Find.2.2=10&selected.RollingReader2.Find.2.2=&selected.HotDocumentLoader.TotalBulkInsert=&selected.HotDocumentLoader.IndividualBulkInsert=&selected.HotDocumentLoader.IndexBuild=&selected.HotDocumentUpdater.Crud=&selected.HotDocumentUpdater.bulkWrite=40&selected.HotCollectionLoader.TotalBulkInsert=&selected.HotCollectionLoader.IndividualBulkInsert=&selected.HotCollectionLoader.IndexBuild=&selected.HotCollectionUpdater.Crud=&selected.HotCollectionUpdater.bulkWrite=40&selected.HotCollectionDeleter.Delete.2.2=40&selected.ScannerLoader.TotalBulkInsert=&selected.ScannerLoader.IndividualBulkInsert=&selected.ScannerLoader.IndexBuild=&selected.SnapshotScanner1Gigabytes.Insert=&selected.SnapshotScanner1Gigabytes.Scan.2.2=10&selected.SnapshotScanner1Gigabytes.ExceptionsCaught.2.2=10&selected.SnapshotScanner5Gigabytes.Insert=&selected.SnapshotScanner5Gigabytes.Scan.2.2=10&selected.SnapshotScanner5Gigabytes.ExceptionsCaught.2.2=&selected.SnapshotScannerAll.Insert=&selected.SnapshotScannerAll.Scan.2.2=10&selected.SnapshotScannerAll.ExceptionsCaught.2.2=&selected.OplogTailer.OplogLag.2.2=&selected.LargeScaleModel.Setup=&selected.LargeScaleModel.ActorStarted=1&selected.LargeScaleModel.ActorFinished=1] sys-perf patch, I significantly increased the buffering of events and amount of concurrency when streaming events to poplar grpc. The throughput of the operations wasn't calculated in the perf ui, and there are some negative durations.    Looking at the generated .ftdc files, the timestamps are out of order, while the cedar calculation of wallclock duration seems to be using the [first and last element listed|https://github.com/evergreen-ci/cedar/blob/e3c5d337c2c8ff346c09d5db95515ab4657d367c/perf/ftdc_rollups.go#L81]. I think the increase concurrency and buffering may be causing us to send them to poplar in different orders. Grpc only guarantees an ordering to events within a single stream, whereas we have many.    I think a straightforward solution would be to use the min/max timestamps instead of the first and last elements, but I'm not sure if poplar is _supposed_ to be guaranteeing a timestamp order when writing to disk, or if there are any other implications of the elements being out of order to deal with.

Title: Where is the long tail of wait times coming from?

However, it appears that this type of thing can occur even below this limit   1) when a lot of tasks are submitted at once   and  2) For a small minority of tasks with exceptional wait times, the long tail, which occurs even at lower-than-average load when one would think the system is operating about as well as it ever does. Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Queues have been longer due to changes in AWS spot behavior
Description: Spot instance termination rates have risen from 2% to a peak of 50%. Furthermore, Evergreen is receiving InsufficientInstanceCapacity responses from AWS at much higher rates. (See attached screenshots for graphs.) Given that the time wasted has not exceeded 11%, it seems like switching entirely to on-demand is not a great long-term solution, since this would roughly double costs on 4xlarge instances. Two possible approaches are:    1. Move as many tasks as possible to smaller instance types. 2xlarge have lower termination rates than 4xlarge, and xlarge have virtually zero terminations. (According to the spot price advisor and our AWS rep, switching regions or instance types, like c5 to m5, will not help.)  2. -Switch to on-demand when spot instances are less available. It's possible we could do this in cases where Evergreen receives InsufficientInstanceCapacity errors.- Edit: This is done. We switched rhel76-large, rhel62-large, ubuntu1804-large, rhel70-large, ubuntu1604-large, and windows-64-vs2017-large to the fallback behavior on 9/23.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Reduce visual friction between 'patch status' and 'base status' in Spruce
Description: The base status in the [patch details view|https://spruce.mongodb.com/version/5f5959dc1e2d173e86e190ba/tasks] is of secondary importance to the patch status. However, the visual priority of patch status versus base status doesn't match the relative importance. Per feedback from [~<USER>, the base status vs. patch status display creates friction for users trying to determine their build results.    !Screen Shot 2020-09-21 at 9.57.03 AM.png|width=100%!     To alleviate this, we could consider swapping the patch status and base status in Spruce, e.g.:   !Screen Shot 2020-09-25 at 11.44.42 AM.png|width=100%!     Making the column switch might make it a bit tricker to swap between the legacy UI and Spruce, since the legacy UI displays base status to the left of patch status.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: attach.xunit_results does not handle files with nested test suites
Description: The xUnit reporting format allows to nest test suites (e.g. using {{TestSuite.addTestSuite()}} in JUnit. However, when the {{attach.xunit_results}} command encounters such a file, it does not recurse into nested test suites, and instead reports no test results being found.    I couldn't find a schema that allows me to verify that nested test suites are indeed part of the specification, but I found an [old Jenkins issue|https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-6545] that shows the problem doesn't just affect Evergreen. More importantly, the JUnit logger used by PHPUnit (see https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/phpunit/blob/master/src/Util/Log/JUnit.php) has been generating files with nested test suites for as long as the git history allows me to check. For reference, this is one of the result files as we are parsing them:      The evergreen output when trying to attach this file is as follows:

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Auto-restart display tasks even if there are blocked execution tasks
Description: Presently, if an execution task encounters a system failure due to a terminated AWS host, its parent display task will attempt to restart, unless the display task has blocked execution tasks.   In the blocked execution tasks case, a user would need to manually restart the display task in order to recover from the AWS host termination.  We should consider auto-restarting display tasks in this case as well.    One potential confusion with the auto-restart is the following scenario. A display task with blocked execution tasks is auto-restarted. Prior to the restart, some execution tasks failed with system failures and other tasks didn't run at all, being blocked. The display task is restarted and all tasks complete successfully. The confusion is that the tasks that had been blocked would have results from multiple executions, while only having truly executed once. Ideally, once EVG-12897 is complete, most users would not need to refer to the multiple executions, since the system failures would no longer be surfaced.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Spruce displays execution tasks intended to be restarted as system failures
Description: Spruce separates display tasks into individual execution tasks in the [patch details|https://spruce.mongodb.com/version/5f43f081d6d80a3602a3c14f/tasks?page=0&taskName=burn_in] view. In contrast, the legacy UI only exposes execution tasks through their [display task|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_v4.4_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_inmem_required_display_burn_in_tests_patch_29e21d0ff597e6dd10bbb9bab4086612339443ca_5f43f081d6d80a3602a3c14f_20_08_24_16_53_31##comparehashes=29e21d0ff597e6dd10bbb9bab4086612339443ca&threads=all].    When a display task encounters a system failure due to an AWS host being terminated, Evergreen will restart it, rather than mark the task as a system failure. In Spruce, because the execution tasks are broken out, they will appear as failed with a system failure in this case. This implies that there's action required from the user to address the system failure, when in reality the task will restart and the failure should resolve on its own.    A potential solution to address this is to display these 'system failed' execution tasks as 'in progress', since for all intents and purposes the task has not yet completed. The task details page can provide further information on whether a task is truly in progress or slated to be restarted, for users interested in differentiating between those two states.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add performance-data.send command to evergreen
Description: As a DAG engineer, I'd like to add the following command to evergreen, such that, we have a simple method for transmitting performance data to expanded metrics w/o using cedar.    *User facing syntax (very similar to json.send, but with an expected schema):*    This command stores performance data for this task and notifies our performance monitoring systems of the update.    Parameters:    file: the JSON-formatted performance data file to save to Evergreen's DB and notify performance monitoring systems of.      The schema for this file is the following:      *Machine workflow*    Evergreen should perform the following in order to execute this command:  1. Validate the schema of the reported data. Fail the command if the data is not formatted correctly.  2. Create a new document with metadata from evergreen:      3. Store this in the same place as json.send, under the performance-data key/name. This should make this data available through the json history routes for our performance monitoring service to consume. Fail the command if unable to store the data.    4. Notify signal processing service of the update:      The credentials for making requests to SPS are already provided in Cedar. *DO NOT FAIL THE COMMAND IF THIS CALL FAILS*. This should generate a warning perhaps, but our service will consider the data for this run on the subsequent run. As long as evergreen has stored the data, we are good.    Summary:  This is more or less the same thing json.send currently does, but with less flexibility, and an extra call to performance monitoring service. We can probably reuse code from json.send and cedar to accomplish the above without much work needed.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Mbox BodyReader cannot handle lines longer than 4096 bytes
Description: msg.BodyReader().Read calls nextLine(), which calls ReadSlice('\n'), which relies on the default bufio buffer size of 4096 bytes. This means that lines longer than 4096 bytes cause patches to fail.

Title: commit queue merge fails when a tag and branch have the same name

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: validate_commit_message task in the commit queue does not work with a commit message across two lines
Description: I had difficulty with [a recent commit|https://github.com/mongodb/mongo/commit/456b0e3ff9c319f494f6defcf62315cd17f8d3a6] where I originally had the commit message across two lines so that each line was <=100 chars, like so:    SERVER-49731 Create an Ident base class for RecordStore and SortedDataInterface and thread a  shared_ptr<Ident> through to the KVDropPendingIdentReaper on drop collection/index.    When I tried to use     evergreen commit-queue merge --project mongodb-mongo-master    to send the patch to the commit queue, the message got completely garbled:    Commit Queue Merge: '=?UTF-8?q?SERVER-49731=20Create=20an=20Ident=20base=20class=20for?=' into 'mongodb/mongo:master'   (https://spruce.mongodb.com/version/5f3bd794e3c331627f992d36/tasks)    I changed it to a single really long line, and it finally worked fine: https://spruce.mongodb.com/version/5f3bd94de3c331627f993096/tasks    Is this expected behavior? Or a bug? What format commit message should I be using? This is the first commit message where this has been a problem. I've committed patches with two-line messages before that the commit queue turned into one line, which was not what I wanted but did get through the commit queue.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Allow projects to predefine applicable spawnhost setup scripts for hosts spawned from task data
Description: Spawning hosts with downloaded task (failure) artifacts has proven incredibly useful. However, extracting the right contents for inspection can be complex due to multiple reasons including:  * Evergreen configuration is a complexity that is (by necessity) abstracted away in some degree to the majority of programmers on a project.  * Projects themselves being complex and having custom scripts/tools for inspecting output to abstract away (to some degree) internal complexities for the large majority of programmers (also necessary).    The recent completion of EVG-5856 gives a predictable place for users to input/execute these scripts. The request in this ticket is to better utilize that box with a set of predefined (in configuration...somewhere) project options in an effort to make these scripts trivially discoverable for newcomers..    For example, server engineers are often spawning hosts from task failures with core dumps to inspect their contents. However finding the core dumps and properly setting up gdb are still mostly trial and error for the uninitiated. The initiated have [published|https://wiki.corp.mongodb.com/display/~<USER>Unarchive+required+files+to+gdb+analyze+coredump+on+spawnhost] scripts [on the interwebs|https://gist.github.com/GWlodarek/681006048f51f3e8195517c00860dfd4] and [other|https://wiki.corp.mongodb.com/display/WT/Troubleshooting+Test+Failures] webpages [link to|https://wiki.corp.mongodb.com/display/WT/Symbolising+mongod+callstack+in+BFs] those [resources|https://wiki.corp.mongodb.com/display/~<USER>Stuff+I+always+forget+how+to+do]. Having these scripts available on the wiki or as gists still leaves them rather undiscoverable.     This ask would also close the remaining feature gap requested in EVG-7484 and probably EVG-7477.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Externally terminated hosts get stuck in an infinite loop
Description: On staging there are three hosts  * i-0608b7b1b6a3e3954  * i-05dd336f25c7b8990  * i-0715f312c4d41be44  that were apparently terminated externally while they were running a task. The task-execution-timeout job is [erroring|https://github.com/evergreen-ci/evergreen/blob/7c56f5ebef25da056b60ed558392d4d6d031d858/units/task_monitor_execution_timeout.go#L189] trying to terminate the host because AWS has forgotten about the instances. At the same time, the hosts are [excluded|https://github.com/evergreen-ci/evergreen/blob/7c56f5ebef25da056b60ed558392d4d6d031d858/model/host/db.go#L684] from the host-monitoring-external-state-check because they're running a task.    It seems to me the fix is to have GetInstanceStatus return a terminated status when we get a InvalidInstanceID.NotFound error from AWS.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Client should return non-zero status when user aborts patch submission at the uncommitted changes prompt
Description: I typically run  {code}  evergreen patch ... && git branch server-xxxxx-evgN  {code}  or similar so that I can keep track of my patch builds.  This works nicely if I change my mind and answer n to the This is a summary of the patch prompt, or if the patch submission fails for some reason.  However, if I answer n to the Uncommitted changes are omitted from patches by default prompt, then the exit code is still 0.  I would expect it to be non-zero, since the patch submission didn't run to successful completion.  The success exit status means the git branch/tag (or whatever followup action I wanted) is still performed, even though the patch wasn't submitted.  This is counter-intuitive given the way that the other prompt works.  Usually when I say n to this prompt it's because I just want to run git status to see what the uncommitted changes are.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Create global_max_hosts functionality
Description: Currently, we are relying on max_host limits to prevent the total number of hosts in the system from becoming too great. We should have a global limit in place so that we can loosen up max_host limits on individual distros, which are frequently pegged at max_hosts and build up very long wait times as a consequence.    use this data:  https://mongodb.splunkcloud.com/en-US/app/search/search?earliest=rt-1m&latest=rt&q=search%20index%3Devergreen%20%22host%20stats%20by%20distro%22&display.page.search.mode=fast&dispatch.sample_ratio=1&display.general.type=events&sid=rt_1596821781.155325    Pegged hosts:  https://mongodb.splunkcloud.com/en-US/app/search/search?earliest=-60m%40m&latest=now&q=search%20index%3Devergreen%20%22host%20stats%20by%20distro%22%20%7C%20spath%20path%3Ddata%7B%7D%20output%3Ddata%20%7C%20fields%20-%20_raw%20%7C%20fields%20data%20%7C%20mvexpand%20data%20%7C%20spath%20input%3Ddata%20%7C%20where%20status%3D%22running%22%20AND%20provider!%3D%22static%22%20and%20distro!%3D%22ubuntu1804-workstation-cluster%22%20and%20distro!%3D%22ubuntu1804-workstation%22%20%7C%20stats%20avg(max_hosts)%20as%20_max_hosts%20avg(count)%20as%20avg_count%20by%20distro%20%7C%20eval%20pegged_floor%3Dfloor(_max_hosts%20*%200.99)%20%7C%20where%20avg_count%20%3E%20pegged_floor%20%7C%20sort%20by%20pegged_floor&display.page.search.mode=verbose&dispatch.sample_ratio=1&display.general.type=visualizations&display.page.search.tab=visualizations&display.visualizations.charting.chart=column&sid=1596824255.157079

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Can you create a patch against a restricted project you don't have access to?
Description: [https://mongodb.slack.com/archives/C0V896UV8/p1596729650420200]    Initial thoughts are yes, but I don't have a restricted project that I don't have access to for testing.    If you can, then we should probably change this issue to a bug, since you could leak Evergreen project variable values in the patch.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Upgrade gopsutil to latest tagged release
Description: The version of gopsutil that we're depending on panics on MacOS when calling {{(*Process).CreateTime()}} due to [a bug that has been fixed in a later version|https://github.com/shirou/gopsutil/issues/799#issuecomment-562764688].    This will require some work to fix grip, which is pinned to an old version of gopsutil.

Title: Host Events Query
Description: Fetch host event data on the ui.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Implement Download method
Description: This should download a single metric type from s3 for a SystemMetrics object.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Hosts table: make columns fixed width

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: API endpoint to reconfigure a patch
Description: We can reconfigure a patch via the UI. We want to do so via the API in the evergreen.py library.    Use case: We're writing code that automatically creates PRs that have specialized testing requirements. We'd like to add the extra tasks to the existing Github PR patch in our code.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Report project failing validation as a PR status
Description: We should add project fails validation to the enum of errors we report on GitHub PRs.  There's no reason not to expose this to users and it happens often enough.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Tasks submitted time should be their ingest_time
Description: The submitted time shown for a task taken from the task's create_time field. Given that a patch task's create time is [that of its base version|https://github.com/evergreen-ci/evergreen/blob/d40dbd00d349328491003a6fc21bc28fae5c8ef6/model/lifecycle.go#L1040] this is confusing. It would be better to show the task's ingest_time.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add Provider to Host Test Query

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Fix versioning logic in email template
Description: There are some assumptions about the legacy versioning scheme (e.g. development releases have an odd minor version) in the email template. It should have logic to handle the new versioning scheme.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Figure out testing story for new release version
Description: We have to:  - Barque, when the repobuilder job is submitted with the new versioning scheme, it should actually build the repo as we expect it to.  - Validate that mr produces the correct feeds.    Possibly add dry run to barque so that it doesn't change the repo state but will log what will be changed.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Evergreen automatically scheduled a zSeries task from March 24th 2020 on August 2nd 2020
Description: Tasks older than 7 days shouldn't be getting automatically scheduled.    https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_v4.4_enterprise_rhel_72_s390x_inmem_sharding_op_query_1_enterprise_rhel_72_s390x_inmem_70c19c844d348774290fdadb9f9bbb0deb5301ad_20_03_24_06_16_46#/log/EV    |Aug 2, 2020 6:45:04 am|Scheduled at Aug 2, 2020, 6:45:03 am|  |Aug 2, 2020 7:00:31 am|Dispatched to host [rhel74-z-12.dallasisv.build.10gen.cc|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/host/rhel74-z-12.dallasisv.build.10gen.cc]|  |Aug 2, 2020 7:00:37 am|Marked as started|

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Allow users to copy-to-clipboard build variant names on patch configuration page
Description: This is useful if a user wants to copy/paste build variant names for documentation, conversations about which task(s) to schedule, etc.    Presently, it is not possible to select them (see this [patch build|https://spruce.mongodb.com/patch/5f244d89d6d80a20695854b1/configure/tasks]).

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Spruce is laggy for patches with large numbers of tasks
Description: This [patch|https://spruce.mongodb.com/version/5f233105e3c3310adaaac655/tasks] is slow to load and relatively less responsive compared to patches with smaller numbers of tasks.  The most severe performance issues in this case have to do with loading large numbers of task boxes. These have been addressed as part of EVG-13179.

Description: In table dropdown filters, the update function should be called if user presses Enter

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: New commits are not being tracked by mongo-go-driver-v1.4
Description: The mongo-go-driver-v1.4 project isn't automatically scheduling waterfall builds for new commits to the branch it's tracking. [~<USER> initially fixed this by using the force run repotracker on save option in the project settings, which kicked off one waterfall run, but the project did not pick up commits the next day either.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Tighter scheduling guarantees between task generation and execution
Description: We'd like to use generate.tasks more generally but the unpredictable timing between generation and dispatch makes things slower than we'd like.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add a configuration option to automatically update the CLI
Description: We could add a option to the ~/.evergreen.yml to automatically update the CLI when there's an update available.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Implement new versioning scheme
Description: This should ideally be a separate implementation from the legacy versioning scheme, whose logic should preferably not change.    For this, we should just implement the existing methods on the mongodb version object, but with their new meanings. This new versioning scheme should only apply for versions 4.5.0 and above.    For example, development series do not exist anymore, but a release that goes into the development repo should be denoted by any non-LTS version which has {{major.quarter.patch}} format and is not followed by {{-rcN}} (special for release candidates).

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Commit queue items on the queue show a graphql error
Description: The link from the CLI takes me [here|https://spruce.mongodb.com/version/5f218fd3850e61275ac8eac9/tasks]:  but I see         until the item reaches the front of the queue

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Can't create empty patches
Description: An empty patch errors:    {code:bash}  $ evergreen patch -p evergreen  Enter a description for this patch (optional):  Unexpected reply from server (500 Internal Server Error): 400 (Bad Request): error getting summaries by commit: error getting patch summaries for commit 'master: EVG-12681 fix for Apple's git (#3834)': couldn't validate patch: Error waiting on patch: 562 - fatal: unrecognized input  : exit status 128  {code}

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Remove nonce error checking for ID token validation
Description: After filing [this issue|https://github.com/okta/okta-jwt-verifier-golang/issues/43], it seems like it should no longer be necessary to check for an error string related to empty nonce claim when returned an ID token [here|https://github.com/evergreen-ci/gimlet/blob/d28831ee71d1d02871f7e6a1c94ec5387430218d/okta/okta.go#L196-L205]. We should be able to remove this check.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Fleet errors for a set of distros
Description: We're getting many errors trying to spawn ubuntu*-arm64-large hosts.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Test new versioning scheme end to end
Description: We should verify that we can correctly put a version greater than 4.5.0 into the development repository. It may also make sense to do this with a release candidate.    This has to be done before we can do the first continuous release.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Can't patch with apple's version of git
Description: The version string for Apple's version of git doesn't match the [regexp|https://github.com/evergreen-ci/evergreen/blob/4dab3e36c27e0487aa3cf2c8c7da37e1c0d29259/operations/patch_util.go#L673]

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Delete CA cert rotation job code

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Remove freebsd from cross-compilation
Description: Nobody uses it anymore so we can get rid of it.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Document or eliminate the delay between version creation and task activation for batch time variants
Description: It seems like there's a delay activating tasks associated with variant that has a batch time. This is based on observation of other tasks in the same version not seeing the tasks as active via the API at the time they're running themselves, and observing that the task was activated at a round number time rather than the time of the commit.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Isolate legacy versioning scheme in bond
Description: A lot of the hard-coded assumptions in bond about the versioning scheme may no longer be valid, so we should verify that it can do critical operations like download new mongodb versions.    Ideally, we should refactor the existing versioning scheme logic into isolated code so that the new versioning scheme does not interfere with existing code.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Investigate how bond versioning scheme needs to change
Description: Bond contains the internal logic for handling building the repos based on release version. However, it's not entirely certain if it will be compatible with the new versioning scheme.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Understand how mr works
Description: This isn't a code change, but mostly to understand how the new versioning changes will integrate with the existing release tool workflow.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Ensure releases and release candidates go to correct repositories
Description: Currently, all unique major.minor releases get their own dedicated path. We will not be doing development/production in these major.minor series anymore. The development repository contains non-releases for each minor version based on the latest commit. The testing repository contains release candidates.    In the new scheme, LTS releases should still get a dedicated repository path (e.g. 5.0) but non-LTS releases (i.e. development and continuous releases) should go into the development repository. Release candidates should still go to the testing repository.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Audit existing usages of old versioning scheme
Description: Once the new versioning scheme is implemented, we should determine where the old versioning scheme logic has to be modified to suit the new versioning scheme.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Implement LTS/continuous/development checks for new versioning scheme
Description: The new versioning implementation should distinguish between LTS releases and non-LTS releases (i.e. continuous and development releases).

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Isolate old versioning scheme logic
Description: This is going to be the first step in supporting both the old and new release versioning schemes. It would entail mostly turning the old versioning logic into its own component so that we can use it and the new versioning scheme at the same time. This will preserve the old versioning scheme and prevent us from needing to make changes to it.    Probably, this will just entail renaming the old versioning scheme legacy so it's obvious that it's the old versioning scheme.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Certificates in cedar all set to 2020-07-30T21:08:57
Description: Cedar rotates a user's certificate when there is 1 week left before it expires. However, every update appears to have been setting the same date, which is now less than one week in the future. This caused the certs to be constantly updated without pushing the expiration far enough to avoid repeatedly re-creating the cert.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Understand drop in read tickets between 6pm and 7pm EST on 7/23/20

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Create script to easily convert mongo documents to json
Description: This would help us quickly turn prod mongodb document data into plain json so that it can be used to seed the local data     This would greatly speed up the process of generating data to seed the local db.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Don't stop starting a host if can't get price information
Description: EVG-12641 might be a situation where hosts can actually start, but the pricing API blocks Evergreen from setting hosts to running. We should put a context on calls to the cachingPriceFetcher and not error if they fail, since we can probably safely continue, since we no longer rely on it to get the cheapest AZ.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add exit status to cedar GRPC client
Description: Just in case the metrics collector fails.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Log volume has increased substantially
Description: We are logging far more to our Splunk index. See the attached screenshot for details. Light blue is Evergreen.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: `evergreen admin enable-service` and `disable-service` fetch blank service flags
Description: They make a request to the legacy admin settings route, which returns an empty struct (except for the banner). We should fix this so it actually returns the existing service flags. Otherwise, these CLI commands will unset all the service flags.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Handle expired refresh tokens by logging out user
Description: If the user has an expired refresh token, the background reauthentication job should clear their login cache as soon as it detects that error so that they must log in again.    Gimlet will have to return a special error message for the case of a user's refresh token being expired.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: LoggingCache does not work as intended
Description: It should be a logging cache stored on the remote service side, not the client side.    It should probably follow the REST model for the logging cache implementation, where it connects to the REST service and makes requests for all the logging cache methods.    We should test the logging cache once it's implemented (along with {{SendMessages}}, which depends on this).

Title: Rename CreateSystemMetricRecord to CreateSystemMetricsRecord and fix panic logging in timber
Description: The naming change is just for consistency with other functions, which use the plural form.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Are task groups clearing the work dir between tasks within the group?
Description: https://github.com/evergreen-ci/evergreen/blob/2a733770e298ce01069e5c916b6a4d8773518c3d/agent/agent.go#L323 doesn't seem to check, but also I think we would be hearing about it if this were the case.    To test this, you can make a task group that writes a file in the first task and then reads that file in the second task.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Generated task ran 8 hours after last task it depended on finished
Description: This task ran on Jul 17 at 1:49am [https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mms_e2e_local_with_daemon_foliage_dd9fa2b4001cd68b7d427b3ff9e6e8924af9b5fb_20_07_16_13_59_36#/log/EV]    It ran over 8 hours after the last task it depended on finished on Jul 16 at 5:05pm    [https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mms_e2e_local_with_daemon_E2E_Local_BRS_Automated_PIT_Restore_ShardedCluster_Blockstore_S3_dd9fa2b4001cd68b7d427b3ff9e6e8924af9b5fb_20_07_16_13_59_36]    This was on rhel70-large over the evening which we would expect to not be constrained on hosts, so we're perplexed what caused the delay    The task was generated long before on Jul 16 at 10:12am [https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mms_evg_foliage_stat_check_init_dd9fa2b4001cd68b7d427b3ff9e6e8924af9b5fb_20_07_16_13_59_36]    This gave us a makespan of 15 hours for the variant. We need to bring that down.    Looking for a root cause of why this 8 hour delay occurred, any steps the evergreen team or we can implement to prevent it in the future.    CC: [~<USER> [~<USER>

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Suggest re-logging into UI if evergreen CLI cannot authenticate user
Description: User refresh tokens expire after 100 days and the only way to get a new token is to log into Okta via the UI. However, the CLI currently just returns 401 unauthorized - it should suggest logging in again if it gets this due to expired tokens.    The way the middleware is written, there's no way to distinguish between different reasons for 401 unauthorized (e.g. unauthorized because ) since the user checking is based on the presence/absence of a {{gimlet.User}} being attached, so it's likely that suggesting logging in again will be the wrong solution since it's just a guess.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Modernize performance tooling terminology
Description: We should update the terminology used in the evergreen performance tooling to be more modern. You can see alternatives [here|https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-knodel-terminology-00.html].  It looks like the term 'whitelist' is the major term to deal with.    ----    As an Evergreen/DAG engineer,  I want to use modern terminology in the code base,  So that the language is acceptable.    ----    AC:  * The terminology described in [this document|https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-knodel-terminology-00.html] has been migrated to more modern terms.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Increase timeout for Task S3 downloads to 30 minutes
Description: In order to support slower network speeds on static hosts (Z,PPC), we want to increase the timeout on downloading artifacts from S3. From manual tests, 30 minutes seems to be a safe threshold.     Example: https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_v4.4_enterprise_rhel_81_ppc64le_failpoints_31b08e7d7e095132b7db3e8f4a4271478cf353ab_20_07_16_02_59_08

Also it mysteriously got scheduled a week after the patch was submitted

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Select All Tasks in Spruce UI Restart dialog menu takes a while for large numbers of tasks
Description: Clicking the Select All Tasks option in the Restart dialog menu for https://spruce.mongodb.com/version/5ed2bbae9ccd4e6de99b9976/tasks took around 7 seconds before all the checkboxes were shown to be selected and the red Restart button could be clicked.    It's possible to also run into an error after a restart hangs:  {{Error while restarting patch: 'Network error: Timeout exceeded'}}

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Remove restriction of hosts greater than half the number of task group tasks
Description: There is a restriction on task groups that the max number of hosts must not be more than half the number of tasks. I believe this was meant to enforce that people use task groups to serialize tasks. However, this doesn't really make sense. Users might want the task group behavior of preserving the directory but also be fine with parallelism.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering

The system logs don't mention an OOM Kill

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: OOM Tracker misses pids
Description: There are times when the OOM tracker misses pids that were OOM killed  [One example|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_master_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_majority_read_concern_off_replica_sets_large_txns_format_2_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_majority_read_concern_off_74ab0cdac56e1cc62fc96d3ca3be3ddfa54f2bcb_20_07_11_23_55_48#/log/S] where we found 12173 but missed 16811 (which is included in the system log)  [Another example|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_master_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_majority_read_concern_off_replica_sets_large_txns_format_2_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_majority_read_concern_off_74ab0cdac56e1cc62fc96d3ca3be3ddfa54f2bcb_20_07_11_23_55_48#/log/S], and [another|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_master_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_dynamic_required_gle_auth_patch_188c858a12705164b7ae5f1ad418821bedd94bb4_5f0caad39ccd4e2f8b9748c4_20_07_13_18_41_44#/log/S#comparehashes=188c858a12705164b7ae5f1ad418821bedd94bb4&threads=maxonly]

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Disable oom tracker in containers
Description: On linux, the container won't have access to the host's dmesg buffer and trying to run it will return dmesg: read kernel buffer failed: Operation not permitted    https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41171349/why-is-a-shell-within-a-docker-container-showing-dmesg-content-from-the-host

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Set read concern majority
Description: We set write concern majority. We should also set read concern majority to avoid reading data that can be rolled back.    Note that the environment variable that sets write concern is in 10gen/kernel-tools. We should use a similar model for setting read concern: Support setting arbitrary read concerns in the app, with a default, and pass read concern majority in the env.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Remove dependence on working directory for clone
Description: The working directory flag for Make-based projects should be removed from the CLI. Users should be able to specify the working directory to clone to, but it should just default to the task's working directory (i.e. {{${workdir}}}).    For golang-based projects, the working directory should be configurable just like the Make one, but it should default to {{${GOPATH}/src/<project_path>}} if none is specified.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Tasks failed to restart
Description: See https://mongodb.slack.com/archives/G979SL0HM/p1594502408091800 for discussion. A system-failed task failed to restart. Reverting task group reset logic commits fixed it.    Tasks that failed to restart before the revert:  * https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongo_release_rhel80_compile_2dae2754daded5fb71a93d19223613850826f75e_20_07_10_19_05_28  * https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongo_release_amazon2_compile_2dae2754daded5fb71a93d19223613850826f75e_20_07_10_19_05_28    Commits I reverted:  * 1c22aa164c4c608a26103d969b4ccc51253595f8  * 20482f76c62c0971e55051de639ce32c48608573    I reverted the first because just reverting the second got me into some pretty unpleasant merge conflicts.

But I'll want to submit the same set of tasks repeatedly as I make changes to the code.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add authentication support to evergreen project subscription POST configuration
Description: As part of the PM-1800 / BF Matching for Patch Builds, DAG would like the build baron server to receive patch failure notifications.    Since this project is implemented as a kanopy service, it is behind [corp secure|https://wiki.corp.mongodb.com/display/SEC/CorpSecure+2.0].     We will be requesting a long lived JWT to grant access to our kanopy service but evergreen will need to support JWT (as a secure field) in order to post to the /patch_build/add_instance endpoint.    A JWT can be used either as a [cookie or an authorization header|https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/DAG-274?focusedCommentId=3276831&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-3276831].

There are some examples you can look at including [buildlogger|[https://github.com/evergreen-ci/cedar/blob/master/buildlogger.proto]] and [perf|[https://github.com/evergreen-ci/cedar/blob/master/perf.proto]].    Think about what users would want to send and how that fits with the functions you have written in the model package.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: LogIterator implementations do not close readers
Description: The LogIterators call {{(pail.Bucket).Get()}} but do not have a way to close the returned manually {{io.ReadCloser}} (e.g. after the {{LogIterator}} is done). This is causing the Windows tests to fail with device/resource busy when trying to clean up the local pail bucket (TestMergeLogIterator).    One possible solution would be to provide a {{Close}} method in the {{LogIterator}} interface.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Versions with blocked tasks aren't marked as complete
Description: We're supposed to mark a version as complete when all its remaining tasks are blocked, but this isn't happening.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Turn on revised dispatcher with dependencies
Description: As far as I can tell from searching Jira, all the known bugs with the revised dispatcher with dependencies are fixed. Running revised instead of revised with dependencies means that we cannot turn off the warning that looks like task compile_unittests in task group compile_all_run_unittests_TG has a dependency on another task ([compile]), which can cause task group tasks to be scheduled out of order, which I believe to be true until we turn on revised with dependencies.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Move Jasper metabuild to Evergreen
Description: The metabuild tool should belong in evergreen since it's an Evergreen-focused feature. It would be good to keep features related to evergreen configuration within Evergreen rather than put it in a repository (which could someday integrate with it, but currently doesn't and likely won't in the near or medium term).

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Shrub should support yaml output
Description: Shrub currently outputs a JSON Evergreen configuration file. While this is fine for things like the agent which just parses it, it's not a very human-readable format. Since we will eventually support local task generation for patches, it would be nice if it had an option to output YAML instead of JSON.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Open Page in the New UI displays on pages that are not yet supported
Description: Presently, clicking this link on a [legacy UI commit page|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/version/mongodb_mongo_master_47dcbeba765b04a829be9c27289e152e24e1a855] results in a GraphQL error. Clicking it on the [task details page|https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_master_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_dynamic_required_lint_eslint_47dcbeba765b04a829be9c27289e152e24e1a855_20_06_25_20_10_38] shows a page in the new UI, as if it were a patch, but then clicking on the Patch breadcrumb leads to the same GraphQL error.    Removing the Open Page in the New UI link on the commit details/task details pages would avoid potential confusion about which pages ought to be supported.    It might also be worthwhile to consider displaying a more specific error message in Spruce when a user tries to navigate to a page that isn't yet supported.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Transition running hosts to running
Description: When we find out a userdata host is running we should skip the provisioning state (and the setupHostJob) and just go straight to running. We'll need to relocate OnUp and setDNSName, maybe to cloud-host-ready.  This will allow us to remove the logic in next_task that lets provisioning hosts run tasks. Also, we could remove the user-data-done job since the agent won't be asking for tasks until userdata has finished running.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Mark terminated instances as terminated in the DB
Description: If AWS tells us a host has terminated we should mark it in the db if we haven't already.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Terminate Spot Instances that are about to terminate
Description: For the spot instance termination event we should terminate the host instead of waiting for AWS to kill it (they aren't running tasks anymore anyway).

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add REST route to handle AWS webhooks
Description: Probably one route will suffice

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Configure host events
Description: Set up AWS to send webhooks for these [events|https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/events/EventTypes.html#spot-instance-event-types]:  * Spot Instance Interruption and/or termination  * instance running    # Create a SNS topic and add a https subscription to send webhooks to evergreen (separate topics/subscriptions for prod/staging?)  # Configure a CloudWatch/EventBridge rule to publish to the topic

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Do not set subprocess.scripting working directory in meta-build
Description: Since it should be set by default to the task's working directory.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add golint for jasper
Description: Jasper tends to be well-documented and it would be good to ensure future devs continue keeping the documentation in a good state.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add region credentials to distros in staging
Description: Add support for the following regions in all ( ?) spawnable distros in staging, and also verify that the instance type is available.   * ap-southeast-2   * Europe (Ireland): eu-west-1   * California: us-west-1

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Changing Instance types not working
Description: Tried changing ubuntu1804-small to c5.large in staging, and tried ubuntu1804-small to c5.xlarge in prod, and both of these received after restarting:    This was also tried like 12 hours after restarting in case there was some catchup time, with no luck.    I wanted to try changing it back to the original instance type, per Jonathan's suggestion, but this isn't an available option, and it probably should be.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Fix compilation of benchmarks
Description: Cedar's benchmarks don't compile because the timber client's function signature changed.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: evergreen YAML should not write AWS credentials to home directory
Description: It should follow what pail does and export environment variables instead (and remove {{~/.aws}} since we can't guarantee that other projects will clean up after themselves).

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Out of Memory Kill detected message on task page is incomplete for some OOM failures
Description: (/) Out of Memory Kill detected (PIDs: 2762) - https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_master_enterprise_ubuntu_task_executor_pool_size_1604_64_bit_concurrency_sharded_replication_57faf552c3acb1dbfacff0020003cbcd3bd36d17_20_06_17_01_34_24/0#/log/S        (x) Out of Memory Kill detected (PIDs: ) - https://evergreen.mongodb.com/task/mongodb_mongo_master_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_inmem_causally_consistent_read_concern_snapshot_passthrough_0_enterprise_rhel_62_64_bit_inmem_2cc507c7c4199aeddd698a277a346b2acfa1c224_20_06_22_01_14_04/0#/log/S        Both of these failures occurred after the changes from [af7fb3b|https://github.com/mongodb/mongo/commit/af7fb3b79ce6ad97b8288c5e7cd64c405375e79b] as part of SERVER-48455.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Commit queue not working for sandbox in staging
Description: For whatever reason, the commit queue for yb_mci in staging seems to not be working (I'm not sure if it's the commit queue for all of staging or for this project in either environment or what).     For example: [this version|https://evergreen-staging.corp.mongodb.com/version/5ef23ae597b1d31c63ef1665] has no merge task associated with it.    Having looked in the DB, the parser project associated with the version _does_ have the merge task and variant, but the tasks/builds don't exist.    This project in staging is important for our own development of the commit queue so we should resolve this.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Passing a config file that doesn't exist should alert the user
Description: If someone tries to pass a config file that doesn't exits, (evergreen -c ~/.non_existent_file.yml) the error they get is can't get project ref: Unexpected reply from server (404 Not Found): no project found named <project name>   It should instead display a more helpful error like  “hey that configuration file doesn’t exist”

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Add more robust buildlogger testing for resmoke
Description: These tests include:   * End-to-end test with curator binary.   * Test to retrieve grouped logs with disjoint times.   * Test to retrieve grouped logs with overlapping tags.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Serialize cleanup jobs
Description: The cleanup jobs queues delete jobs in parallel even if previous jobs haven't completed. We should consider adding a scope or figuring out some other way of serializing these jobs.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Support go modules in scripting harness
Description: Currently, it assumes that the repo uses vendored dependencies. This should be investigation into how to use go modules and how to change the scripting harness to support modules. There should be follow-on work to integrate it with subprocess.scripting and the golang config generator.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Use simple service users in barque
Description: Instead of using LDAP, it should use the gimlet cached user manager backed by the database.         Ideally, this should be implemented such that curator shouldn't need to be updated, and the credentials will query against the service users in the database and not against LDAP.         There shouldn't need to be any UI/REST support for the features.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Patch base commit link goes to patch in old UI, not base version

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Auto-populate working directory if not specified in subprocess.scripting
Description: If the working directory is not specified for subprocess.scripting, the code most likely will not work. However, most of the time, it seems like using the agent's working directory should be sufficient as an auto-populated field. This will help the jasper generator not need to depend on the host's working directory (which enables local jasper build generation to be passed directly with a patch).

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Remove timeline and summary pages
Description: Research has found that there are no users of the timeline and summary pages. We should remove them.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Document process for adding a new greenbay test to appropriate README

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: implement panic recovvery handlers for worker implementations

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: amboy support for new bson library

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: add annotate method for message composer.
Description: have method that we can use to add arbitrary (quasi structured data) to any message composer. We'll mostly add it to the base type, but may override (particularly for fieldsMessage) in some implementations.    The main use case, initially would be to be able to use existing messages but also write logging helpers that add request ids for better traceability in request logging.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: support autodetection of distribution
Description: the {{artifacts}} subcommand currently detects what architecture we are on, but not the distribution (when run on linux). There are presently a number of varied approaches to doing this in drivers-specific code paths, most notably in the [download-mongodb.sh|https://github.com/mongodb-labs/drivers-evergreen-tools/blob/master/.evergreen/download-mongodb.sh#L8-L42] script used by most drivers running on evergreen. Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: ConvertToComposer does not set log level on a fieldMessage on calls after the first
Description: We are logging startHosts success messages at Error but should be logging them at Info.    https://github.com/evergreen-ci/evergreen/blob/master/hostinit/runner.go#L84 has the side effect of setting the message type to Error even though it doesn't log, so when the next line runs, it logs at the Error level even though it should lot at Info.    I think this is because fieldMessage.setup() sets the metadata field to &Base only if it is not already set https://github.com/mongodb/grip/blob/master/message/fields.go#L117. As a result, ConvertToComposer, which is called by all *When methods even if they noop, only sets the level of a fieldMessage the first time it runs.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Allow processes to close their resources gracefully and reconsider sharing connections between remote clients and processes
Description: The close method would help with cleaning up resources because the SSH library has to open an SSH session, which should be gracefully shut down. The only resource we really need to stop in the local is the transition/reactor goroutines in basic/blocking process to ensure the executor is closed.    The connection sharing is mostly a problem because it ties any methods called to the remote process (e.g. RPC process) to the lifetime of the RPC client. For example, if you got an RPC process and then closed the RPC client that gave you the process, the process, which should be logically separate but is actually dependent on the RPC client connection, would be unusable after that, which is not exactly desirable behavior.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Allow Command.Run to be more configurable
Description: Currently, the only configurable behavior in Command.Run is the creation of the underlying processes via {{(*Command).ProcConstructor()}}. However, for some use cases, it needs to behave differently when run. For example, by the semantics of the {{sshManager}}, {{(*sshManager).CreateProcess()}} should logically configure the command and run it over SSH.  Since {{sshManager}} itself relies on {{Command}} for its underlying behavior, the in-memory {{Command}} needs {{Run()}} to actually serialize its fields into JSON input to the CLI on the remote machine over SSH in order to run the command with the correct semantics.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Packages in server requirements should work with python 3.6
Description: The server build system sets a python minimum of python 3.6, not python 3.7. However, shrub requires 3.7. This creates an unpleasant situation on Ubuntu 18.04 (which is the image type used for virtual workstations), where the system python3 is not acceptable for installing the `dev-requirements`. You can work around by using the toolchain python, which is py37, but this isn't great. We should ensure that our tools work on the most commonly deployed Ubuntu LTS without needing the mongodbtoolchain.

Description: the TIG team has found a couple of situations where jasper deadlocks in tests that are signaling processes over GRPC, and also doing Get calls of the terminated processes. This reproduces pretty consistently in evergreen and happens on Linux.    We don't have a unit test that covers this kind of workload, and I think that's the place to start this investigation.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: New repobuilder jobs should clear .olddata from previous runs
Description: When the app server restarts in the middle of a repobuilder job, it will leave behind the {{.olddata}} directory if it was running {{createrepo}} when it restarted. This will cause future {{createrepo}} commands in later repobuilder jobs to fail since the old data directory still exists. We should remove it before we run {{createrepo}} (this should be fine to do since the jobs are protected by scopes on the distro and have to run serially on each distro).    Logs: https://mongodb.splunkcloud.com/en-US/app/search/search?q=search%20index%3Dbarque%20build-repo.distro.rpm.repo.c0860eb1-cce1-4207-8f47-50c786814d87&display.page.search.mode=verbose&dispatch.sample_ratio=1&earliest=1590513780&latest=1590528225&sid=1590528302.2773197

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: make it possible to bootstrap a certdepo from an empty config
Description: if everything's zero'd out then you can't start the app, because the filedepot will be the empty string and the cert depo options will be nil.     I think we need to have some omitempty to fix it, this might be an issue only for existing services that are adding SSL.     Relatedly, I'd like to make sure that the configuration in the database looks reasonable (this probably means putting a lot of omit emptys and then cleaning up the database) because currently (particularly for the cert depot) we set a bunch of zero values in the database and then override them in memory, so you can't really see what things are set to.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering

It should be able to send requests to either the REST service or RPC service.

Title: Scoped jobs that are undispatchable should have scopes removed or be deleted

One possible reason is that jobs with a {{DispatchBy}} requirement may not be able to run if too long has passed, so they will be stuck unable to dispatch and also will not clear their scopes. For jobs that have scopes and are stuck in progress but can't be re-dispatched due to {{DispatchBy}}, we should just unset their scopes and mark them complete.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Validate access and ID tokens, acquire refresh token
Description: The token can be easily verified by using the /introspect endpoint to validate the token. However, this requires one network call per authorization, which has to be done often. If we don't care about performance and number of requests made, this might be good enough.    The best way to do this would be to add application logic for caching and periodic refreshing of the keys from the authorization server. If the access token is expired, get a new one using the refresh token. If the access token key does not match the authorization server key, try getting a new access token first. If the keys still do not match, only then do we try getting the authorization server keys. That way, will only ask for new keys if the validation fails (due to key mismatch) or if the caching TTL has expired.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Remove group check from Okta
Description: It seems like any users who can log into Okta is an employee (which is all we care about), so we don't have to perform the group check that is done in LDAP  Therefore, we can remove (or make optional) much of the logic with checking the user's groups from userinfo and validating the access token.         It seems like this is somewhat annoying to do because the ID token validation expects a nonce to be provided, but there is none for an ID token received from refreshing tokens. There is [some ambiguity|https://github.com/IdentityServer/IdentityServer4/issues/2180] about what to do since the ID token doesn't have a nonce when we refresh tokens. [This thread|https://bitbucket.org/openid/connect/issues/1025/ambiguity-with-how-nonce-is-handled-on#comment-44979149] suggests that a refresh grant should not return a nonce, so the Okta library may simply be wrong.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Handle reauthorization after given expiration time
Description: The current LDAP manager reauthorizes users after a TTL (configured to one hour right now) by checking the user's LDAP groups. The new Okta user manager should also do some kind of periodic checks against Okta.    Checking the user group (in a similar way as LDAP is currentl ydone) requires using the user's access token, which expires after some amount of time. When the token is expired, we have to handle getting a new one. This could potentially be achieved by requesting refresh tokens.    If the access token and refresh token are invalid, then we have to redo authentication to get more tokens.         There's also the possibility that we can't use refresh tokens (i.e. due to security policies), so we might have the user go through silent reauthentication (without a login prompt). If we go this route, we have to somehow know where to redirect the user.

Title: Create Jasper build CLI that can generate evergreen configs from golang build files
Description: Mostly, this should just be feeding a yaml config file into the golang evergreen config generator. For now, this should just be a convenience to test the generator quickly.         We should also create an explicit Jasper binary in {{cmd}}.

Name: The MongoDB Engineering
Title: Support self-restarting processes
Description: In order to support long-running processes in jasper managers, we have to provide a means for processes to restart (essentially clone) themselves once they have exited.
